name: The Greenhouse Effect
summary: How does the greenhouse effect operate, and how have humans altered it?

body: Greenhouse gases in the Earth’s atmosphere regulate global temperatures. Sunlight is able to travel through our atmosphere freely and is either absorbed or reflected by the Earth. Absorbed sunlight is transformed into heat, which forms longer-wave radiation and does not pass as freely through greenhouse gases. Instead, most of this heat is re-radiated and warms the Earth.(Check out A for more on this!)

sections.subheading: How did we contribute to this?
body: This process is completely natural, without it, temperatures on Earth would not sustain life. However, industrial activities have resulted in the additional production of greenhouse gases, which have raised atmospheric CO2 levels from 280 to 412 parts per million in the last 150 years. The IPCC conclude that there is above a 95% probability that human production of these gases has resulted in increased temperatures (Look at Y for more detail).

Climate change deniers still try and dispute this, but the science is pretty clear… The sun follows an 11-year cycle that determines the frequency and size of sunspots, which effect the amount of energy the sun emits. However, this cycle has remained consistent since 1750 and average energy output from the sun has not increased enough to account for the amount of warming experienced.

sections.subheading: What can I do about this?
body: Where possible, cut the amount of greenhouse gases you produce. We’re not just talking about taking the bus; think about the energy you use in your home. Do you need to use the tumble dryer? Can you take a shorter shower? How much energy goes into producing the products you buy? Look at our post on Carbon offsetting for some ideas on how you can balance out your own carbon footprint. Remember, supply meets demand, a great way to tackle energy-intensive institutions (like fashion) is through taking your demand elsewhere!

name: Yearly Warming
summary: What is yearly warming, and how does this impact on humans?

body: Global Warming has triggered exponential growth in global temperatures, resulting in long-term climatic changes. Since the industrial revolution (mid-1800's), global temperatures have increased by an average of 1'C. To the average person, the difference of one or two degrees might not seem that big of a deal. So why is this significant? To heat the oceans, land masses, and the atmopshere by even one degree centigrade, enormous amounts of heat are required, and the impact on global climates will be major. For example, a decrease in 1-2'C has previously caused a Little Ice Age in the UK. If global temperatures continue to rise by more than 1.5'c, we will see wide spread coral bleaching and the destruction fo the Great Barrier Reef. Current estimated global temperatures are 1.2'C above pre-industrial levels.

Two thirds of warming has occured since the 1970s due to increases in consumption, single use plastic and mass agriculture. If these practices - defined as business as usual - continue, the IPCC predict that a warming of 4.8'C could be seen in 100 years, exceeding the global maximum for dangerous levels of 2'C. However, fluctuations in temperatures between regions mean that this warming could be much greater in certain areas. Climate relates to weather which is far more unpredictable and localised. Fluctuations can be impacted by the time of day and seasons, as well as changes in the reflectivity of the Earth's surface (see A and F for more on Albedo effect and climate feedback), and changes in the concentration of greenhouse gases within the atmopshere.

sections.subheading: What can you do to help?
body: The main contributors to climate warming are burning fossil fuels, agriculture, and deforestation. While the largest corporations are responsible for the vast majority of greenhouse gases, individuals can make a difference by ensuring they move away from a consumption-heavy lifestyle and don't create additional demand for damaging practices. You could try going meat-free a few times a week, and choose products grown and manufactured as close to home as possible to reduce transport miles. Try buying second hand, websites such as Ebay or Depop allow you to find clothes from brands you're already familiar with, at a discounted price - just because they're pre-loved! Within your household, you can look into switching energy providers to renewable companies such as Bulb, Pure Planet or Octopus (there are so many to choose from!). You can save energy and reduce bills by unplugging unused devices and turning lights off - all of these options should save you some money too!
Whatever choices you make have the potential of creating a positive reaction chain and take demand away from harmful practices.

name: Albedo Effect
summary: What's the Albedo effect and how does it contribute to climate change?

sections.__comment9__: Contents of the section which can be seperated into multiple paragraphs
body: The Albedo Effect is where light surfaces reflect sunlight and redirect solar energy out of the atmosphere.This is mostly from the Arctic and Antarctic; as well as glaciers, light clouds, dust, smoke and pollen.

Albedo is a form of climatic feedback resulting in a small cooling effect. The amount of solar energy absorbed or reflected drives climate and weather patterns. As glacial melting increases, more dark ocean is revealed, absorbing solar energy and creating a positive feeback loop that is accelerating global warming.

sections.subheading: What's happening with the Arctic now?
body: As highlighted in the annual Arctic report card, the average annual land surface air temperature north of 60° N for October 2018-August 2019 was the second warmest since 1900. Warming air temperatures and the positive feedback mechanism of the albedo effect is driving changes in the Arctic environment that affect ecosystems and communities on a regional and global scale.
The Greenland Ice Sheet is losing nearly 267 billion metric tons of ice per year and currently contributing to global average sea-level rise at a rate of about 0.7 mm per year.

name: Net Zero
summary: What actually is Net Zero, and is it enough?

body: Net Zero describes a 100% reduction in CO2e* achieved when the same amount of CO2e produced by the UK is also being removed from the balance. So, it doesn’t mean no emissions at all, only that the UK will become carbon neutral. The amended national goal of a 100% reduction in CO2e by 2050 relevant to 1990 will require emissions to fall at an average rate of 15 MtCO2e per year, the equivalent to 3% of total emissions in 2018. But – how are our emissions measures?

GHG estimates are published by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) – A branch of the Civil Service which advice the government and are responsible for monitoring the countries progress with this target. So, what criteria is used to measure our emissions? The BEIS use what are called production-based emissions – so the emissions that the UK is responsible for producing, rather than those we consume. This could also be thought of as primary versus secondary emissions. The emissions included must also be territorial – that means anything produced within the UK no matter where the party responsible for these emissions are registered. That also means that UK companies who conduct business and produce emissions abroad, say through a factory, are discounted from predictions. Estimates also include the activities of people within the UK, both from British citizens and non-UK visitors. Finally, it includes land use within the UK – from peatland, to forests, to agriculture.

Due to pressure from the public and the Committee on Climate Change, new Net Zero targets now account for international aviation and shipping (IAS), and from 2020 include more thorough estimates from peatbogs. IAS emissions have increased by over 80% since 1990 and demand is likely to increase further. Poorly managed peatland is a large source of CO2 in the UK, responsible for emitting an estimated 23m tonnes in 2017. For context, that is only 5m tonnes less than the total amount of CO2 removed by all the vegetation in the UK. Essentially, almost ruling out the role that vegetation plays in removing greenhouse gases produced by the UK.

sections.subheading: Is there anything I can do?
body: So, the UK faces a real challenge to reach net zero by 2050. It will require a major move away from fossil fuels towards renewables and natural gas and strict policy. Therefore, it’s essential that as voters we ensure government accountability and put continued pressure to reach this target. However, we can also all play our part. As renters, we don’t have the ability to stick some solar panels on our roof – however, we can still run our homes with renewables. There are so many renewable energy companies out there, and many of them charge you less for the energy they supply than those who source their energy from fossil fuels. The link below will give you an insight into the many options out there. Just pop your landlord/lady/ estate agents and email and switch today. Many of the companies handle the switch for you, so it won’t take long – and you’ll be one step closer to making your own life, and the UK, a bit more carbon neutral.

*(CO2e or Carbon Dioxide equivalent means the impact of all greenhouse gases, in their equivalent potency compared to carbon dioxide.  So - the equivalent amount of CO2 needed to create the same amount of warming produced by other greenhouse gases, like methane or nitrous oxide. This way, you can discuss all greenhouse gases with only one number. If you’re still confused, check out this Guardian article: https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/apr/27/co2e-global-warming-potential)

name: Feedback
summary: What's climatic feeback and how does it work?

body: Climatic feedback loops are aspects of the climate which can enhance or diminish climate change effects. These are either positive or negative. Negative feedback destabilises and will diminish effects of climate warming, whereas positive feedback creates loops which enhance warming processes.

As more greenhouse gases are produced, more heat is trapped in our atmosphere. Warmer temperatures result in more evaporation within the water cycle, resulting in higher percentages of water vapour in the air. Water vapour traps more heat, which leads to more evaporation, which leads to more water vapour… you get the idea.

As temperatures increase, permafrost in the arctic circle is melting. This is revealing organic material that has been trapped for centuries – since the last glacial period. Without the ice conserving it, these materials decompose producing large quantities of methane. Methane is much more effective at trapping heat than CO2. Over a period of 20 years, it will be 80x more potent.

Parts of Russia – in particular Siberia - are experiencing temperatures +20-25oC hotter than usual. On June 20th, 2020,  temperatures in Verkhoyansk, Siberia soared to 38oC. Average temperatures this time of year are around 0oC.

sections.subheading: Are we reaching a tipping point?
body: Such heat will have a lasting impact on the Arctic’s permafrost and sea ice. These positive feedback loops have resulted in the tipping point theory, an idea that we may soon reach ‘runaway global warming’, where temperatures accelerate at a rate too fast for effective mitigation and reduction.

name: Water
summary: Water and the continual global threat associated with it.

sections.subheading: Water and the continual threat associated with it
body: Water Scarcity describes the lack of freshwater resources to meet global demand. Whilst water is a vital human resource used daily, less than 1% of the Earth's water supply is suitable for human consumption. This leaves 20% of the planets population (1.52 billion people) walking an average of 3.5 miles a day to get water. Differences in demand, accessibility, and availability between countries creates disproportion in water quantities between groups of people and leads to water poverty.

Precipitation differences between countries and regions is one reason for water disparity. For example, Uganda has the lowest access to clean water close to home with 38% access. In Niger, 4.1% of the poorest people have access to water, which rises to 72% for the wealthiest individuals. A lack of closed water systems means access to clean, contamination-free water is low. Approximately 300,000 children under 5 die from dirty water and poor-hygeine related illnesses every year.

Whilst water poverty is more common in developing countries, 14.6% of the UK also experience this issue. The water poverty rate is double the average for single pensioners, unemployed households and those in the bottom quintile for income. Climate change creates increased resourced scarcity, and alongside increased demand this has caused water bills to become more expensive. This increases the number of households in water poverty and puts people at risk of getting into debt and being taken to court over underpayments. However, it is illegal for water companies to cut supplies off.

sections.subheading: What can you do to help?
body: Save water and support charities helping to tackle water issues. Monitor your water usage to check for leaks - if usage is higher than usual without good reason you most likely have a leak. Fixing this can save up to 11,000 litres of water as well as reducing your wastr bill. In most cases this is the landlords responsbility if you are in rented accomodation. You can also install a tap aerator - these are inexpensive attachments that can be placed on taps to save up to 80% of water! You can also support charities such as Water Aid and Oxfam to help those less fortunate both in the UK and Global South. This support can be through raising awareness, donations, or even fundraising.

name: Kyoto Protocol
summary: What was the Kyoto Protocol and how successful has it been?

body: The Kyoto Protocol is an agreement through the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), agreed by countries at a summit in Kyoto in 1997. It was the first such agreement between countries to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It focused on the reduction of 6 key greenhouse gases. Each country had a different 'assigned amount' by which they had to reduce their emissions, based on their current emissions level and level of economic development - so less developed countries were allowed more emissions to enable them to develop.

Each country's emissions target was calculated as a a reduction target from their 1990 emissions ('base level'), with the aim to make this reduction by 2012 (a date later extended). Across all nations participating this would equate to a 5.2% cut in emissions between 1990 and 2012. As of 2013, 192 'parties' (or nations) had signed the Kyoto Protocol, though many of these had not ratified it (i.e. put it into policy) and not all who signed were assigned emissions targets.

The emissions included in each country's targets did not include international aviation or shipping - two huge causes of emissions. Although legally binding, in reality there was little incentive for countries to comply. Many never ratified the agreement, including big emitters such as the USA, in part because they found it unfair that some other countries were not told to reduce their emissions. It didn't come into force until 2005 - by which point major emitters such as China and India had emerged, who had not been factored in and given emissions targets.

In short,  no! Emissions actually rose 40% globally over the 1990-2012 period - some countries met their targets but the increasing emissions of others wiped out this progress. Since then, there have been multiple amendments, including:
- The 2010 Cancun Amendments where 76 countries responsible for 85% of emissions signed voluntary pledges to cut emissions.
- The 2012 Doha Amendments - an agreement to extend the protocol period from 2012 to 2020.
- The 2015 Paris Agreement - this effectively replaced the Kyoto Protocol, with nearly every country agreeing to aim to keep global warming below 1.5 degrees celsius, or at least below 2 degrees.

name: Politics
summary: How can we influence politics to bring aboout climate change action?

sections.subheading: How can politics influence climate change?
body: Politics can decide how climate change is prioritised (if at all!) by those with the power to make large-scale changes. Political decisions range from encouraging individual change through taxes or bans, to allocating budgets for climate change adaptation and mitigation. In the UK, recent examples of policy change include a pledge for net zero by 2050 and a proposed ban on new petrol and diesel cars. Politics is done on various levels, all of which you can influence by voting and other means.

Different councils have different powers, depending on if they are a county council, metropolitan borough council and so on. However generally they have power over recycling, local transport, housing, local economic strategy and much more. Influencing council decisions can be done by asking them to declare a climate emergency (or how their actions are matching their declaration), through getting involved in planning consultations (ask how new housing is energy efficient or joins existing cycling networks) or through asking for food waste caddies to be standard in your area.

Some decisions in the UK are devolved to Scottish and Welsh governments, while metropolitan mayors also have increased power such as London's Mayor having responsibility for Transport for London. Environmental matters are devolved in some cases, so if you're in Wales or Scotland question your local representative about these issues. Mayor's usually hold a form of public questions - the State of London debate for example - where you can put questions directly to them, or get in touch with your local Assembly member.

MPs have a vote in Parliament on policy regarding climate change, and your MP may sit on a committee or be a cabinet member who has more influence. Write to your MP regarding an upcoming vote to ask them to vote a certain way - there are templates online. Or ask your MP to raise an early day motion or directly ask the PM a question at weekly PMQs. You can also sign petitions on the government website - they have to respond if they reach enough signatures.

There are ways of influencing political decisions outside, or alongside, the formal settings of government. For example, joining protests such as the 'Fridays for Future' Climate Strikes can be really effective in showing politicians how much support there is for a certain issue. You could also get involved with a lobbying group such as Greenpeace or Friends of the Earth, who lobby companies and governments for change. Such groups can be local, national or international, and many offer volunteering roles if you wanted to get more involved. You can also vote with your money, through choosing to buy or boycott products and companies that align or don't align with your ethical and environmental values (this is sometimes dubbed buycotting, because everyone loves a pun).

name: Travel
summary: How can we travel in a more climate-friendly way?

sections.subheading: How does travel affect climate change?
body: Aviation accounts for at least 2% of global emissions, and this number is rising. Emissions caused by flight's are not usually counted in a country's emissions totals, as there is debate as to whether the emissions should count for the country of take off or landing. This means it can be difficult to monitor and account for emissions from flying accurately. A flight causes 254g of emissions per kilometre per person - compared to only 6g for the Eurostar! This is an unequal issue too, like much of climate change. Just 15% of people in the UK take 70% of flights, and a majority of the world's population has never flown. A return economy flight from London to New York emits as much as the average person in Ghana emits in a whole year.

sections.subheading: Where do I start with cutting down flights?
body: Talk to your boss about the 'Climate Perks' scheme with Possible - it allows employees 2 extra days leave a year for travelling without flying. Look at seat61.com for a great place to start planning travel - it offers information on how to get anywhere in Europe (and beyond) without flying. Look into railcards! You can get a discount on trains for being 16-25, travelling as a couple or group and more.

sections.subheading: What if I need to fly?
body: Cutting out flying altogether is unrealistic for many people, whether due to work, long distance relationships or family abroad. So when you do need to fly, try the following.
Fly economy - more people can be accommodated in economy than business or first class, reducing the number of flights needed.
Fly direct - most of a flight's emissions are in the take off and landing, so flying direct minimises this.
Fly less often - save up your holidays for one longer break and travel around on public transport once there, rather than several shorter holidays.

sections.subheading: What can be done alongside individual action?
body: Here are some policies being discussed to reduce the number of flights taken and their impact:
- Reducing the cost of public transport through subsidies to encourage the use of trains and buses over flying.
- Requiring airlines to offset the carbon emissions of all their flights.
- Introducing a frequent flyer levy - those who fly the most would face hefty taxes on their flights.
- New technology such as biofuel or battery powered planes could be further developed.

name: Urban
summary: How do urban areas impact on, and become impacted by, climate change?

sections.subheading: How do urban areas link to climate change?
body: By 2050, 68% of the world's population will live in urban areas. Despite occupying only 2% of the world's land mass, cities account for over 70% of the world's CO2 emissions.
Urbanisation is seen as a sign of economic development - the same economic development which leads to increased environmental damage through higher levels of consumption and emissions.

sections.subheading: Why do cities contribute more to climate change?
body: Cities tend to be the centre for emissions-intensive activity such as manufacturing, transport and commerce in a country. Cities also act as urban heat islands (or UHIs). Materials sich a concrete and asphalt - common in cities - absorb heat. As buildings are constructed at higher density in cities than elsewhere, these materials increase the temperature nearby - significantly enough to alter the local micro-climate. This means more energy is needed to cool these buildings, plus adds to the higher temperatures caused by global warming.

sections.subheading: Can urban areas and climate change interact positively?
body: Urban areas tend to be the centre of research and innovation, including into climate change. City governments are also often able to implement changes outside of, or on top of, national policy, and implement change such as in eco-friendly housing or public transport initiatives, more quickly than national policy can change.

The higher density in urban areas can actually be beneficial - for example through reducing the amount of land used as more tower blocks are built, and through reducing the distance people have to commute and car usage, normally. Cities also tend to see more investment in such areas as transport, water and energy systems than rural areas, giving more scope for change.

name: Extinction Rebellion (XR)
summary: Who are XR and what role have they played in tackling climate change?

body: Extinction Rebellion are a global movement undertaking non-violent action to compel governments to act on climate change.
They have 3 main demands:
1. Tell the truth - declare climate and ecological emergency.
2. Act now - reach net zero carbon emissions by 2025 (take a look at Z for more on this!).
3. Act beyond politics - create and be led by the decisions of a Citizens Assembly

sections.subheading: What has XR achieved so far?
body: XR protests prompted the UK Government to declare a climate emergency in 2019.
The UK became the first major economy to pass a net zero emissions law.
The House of Commons has established a UK Climate Assembley. This brings together a group, who are representative of the UK population, to discuss and advise on policy relating to net zero.
Scientists for XR are a group of scientists who support the aims and actions of XR - their aim is to amplify information regarding the truth about the climate and ecological emergency.
Over 1000 scientists from all over the world have signed a declaration supporting civil disobedience protests to urge government action.

sections.subheading: How can you become an activist?
body: Beginning your activism journey can be overwhelming - we understand that! Here are our top tips about where to start:

1. Do your research and find out what matters. For example, learn about the science behind climate change so you feel confident when involved in a conversation about it. Every little helps and clarity is always key.
2. Find (and join) your local action groups. XR are one of many communities coming together to tackle climate change and spark change

3. Always feel like you have something to offer - you don't need to do something big like civil disobedience to be an activist. Activism can also be everyday actions, such as: donating to a charity, supporting brands who challenge the status quo and talking to (and educating) your friends and family about important issues!

name: Health
summary: How can acting on climate change improve our health?

body: As you know, we face a choice between two pathways: business as usual, or turning the tide on climate change. Climate change and human health are interconnected - trends in climate change impacts, exposures and vulnerabilities show an unacceptably high level of risk for current and future health of people all over the world. However, if we choose a greener future we have the option to drastically increase the health of the planet and ourselves.

sections.subheading: Lack of progression theatens our personal health and healthcare systems
body: Air pollution and aeroallergens contribute to respiratory diseases, cancers and risk of heart attack - this also causes global warming. Hotter temperatures and changing rainfall patterns increase the incidence of illness being spread by food, water and insects. Lower quality and quantity of water has knock on effects for food and therefore our nutrition. Ongoing changes and severe impacts, combined with the socio-economic impacts of climate change, contribute to an increased risk of mental ill-health.

sections.subheading: Mitigating climate change has co-benefits for people and the planet
body: Co-benefits arise from the changes in harmful exposure (e.g. reducing air pollution) and health-related behaviours from  actions. The below interventions are some of many that have the potential to impact future sustainability of the planet, as well as improve health and wellbeing.

Active travel helps to reduce air pollution from road transport, particularly passenger cars (61% of GHG from road transport across Europe). By avoidng passenger cars and choosing walking, running or cycling to your destination, you can incorporate your daily exercise into your routine (making it a lot easier to get out of the way!!). Being active everyday can reduce the risk of: breast cancer, vascular dementia, heart disease and depression.

Green spaces improve air quality, particualrly in urban areas. They also provide huge benefits for biodiversity, such as increasing current species populations or re-wilding old ones! These lush green spaces also provide areas for people - such as yourselves - to relax, excercise, learn and spend time with others. This improves wellbeing by enabling social integration; improving your mood and self-esteem; and reducing feelings of stress. Ecotherapy practices are rooted in these benefits - research has shown it can help with feelings of depression. You could start by trying gardening (in your garden or local park - plant helpful seeds to help your local environment), growing food (tasty!), building an animal habitat, nature photography or nature crafts!

Reducing your intake of animal products is perhaps the single biggest way to reduce your impact on the environment. Each day, a person who eats a vegan diet saves 1,100 gallons of water, 45 pounds of grain, 30sq ft of forested land and 20lbs CO2 equivalent. At the same time, cutting out animal products has a myriad of benefits for you! This way of eating has potential to recude your chance of heart disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes and cancer. Why not try vegan food for one day, one week, one month? You might find it turns into lifetime! Go see the letter V in our ABClimate series.

name: Energy
summary: What are the different sources of energy? How do they help or hinder the climate crisis?

body: Energy is power derived from using physical or chemical resources. It helps us do all kinds of things by creating power for: light, heat, cars, machines, TVs and charging our phones. We simply can't live without it!!!

sections.subheading: How do energy sources generate power?
body: Firstly, take one source. This can be fossil fuel, nuclear, renewables, or biomass. Secondly, convert the source into energy. Then, the reaction from this conversion makes a turbine move. This movement powers a generator. Finally, the generator transfers it's power to the output (the thing it's providing power for like plugs in your home).

sections.subheading: Fossil Fuels: Coal, Gas and Oil
body: Fossil fuels are a source of non-renewable energy. They contribute the most to our energy production. Fossil fuels are derived from (yep - you guessed it!)... fossils! These fossils were formed from the remains of organisms that lived millions of years ago. It's predicted that we'll run out of this source in around 50 years - and perhaps that's a good thing! When fossil fuels burn, they release carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, adding to the greenhouse effect and accelerating global warming.

Like fossil fuels, these are non-renewable sources. Sources of nuclear energy are more efficient than fossil fuels - 1kg of nuclear fuel produces millions of times more energy than 1kg of coal. Most of the time, nuclear power is safe. However, if there is an accident, radioactive material can be released into the envrionment that can be hazardous to health for thousands of years. This is what happened in Chernobyl.

sections.subheading: Biomass: Wood, Plants, Manure and Household Waste
body: Biomass is a type of renewable energy source, generated from heating organic matter. We've used biomass energy since the earliest cave men made wood fires! If you've got to this point, you might be thinking... better for the planet if we keep burning trees, plants and waste? We thought that too. You're absolutely right! If Biomass is going to work it requires a sustainable approach, meaning that the source is replaced after using.

There are 2 main positives to 'doing' biomass sustainably. 1. It can be carbon-neutral: we convert biomass into energy by burning it. This emits carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, like fossil fuels. However - and this is the important bit - trees and plants have the potential to capture the same amount of carbon dioxide emitted through photosynthesis, meaning that any carbon made by the process is cancelled out by producing biomass. And 2. It hels us with waste management! When we use household waste as a biomass energy source, it avoids sitting in our bins and landfill. This plays a vital role in creating a circular economy of energy and waste. This means that we can design waste and pollution out of society by using it to be productive - making our energy!
Renewable energy is derived from natural resouces that keep on giving: wind, the sun, and water. Renewable energy sources don't emit greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming.

This energy source has more benefits than just being green, too! It expands access to energy, creates jobs, lowers energy bills and makes energy sources more resilient! A great example of this in practice can be seen at Casa Sol Bed and Breakfast in San Juan, Puerto Rico. This eco-hotel has it's own water supply and collection facility along with solar panels for energy. After the devastating hurricanes (Irma and Maria), Casa Sola began helping their local community by providing a source of water and power, such as storing medicine. Now this community are continuing to build on these methods in preparation for the inevitable 'next time', so they can continue to be self-sufficient in an emergency situation.

name: Oceans
summary: How do the Oceans operate, and how is climate change affecting them?

body: Oceans are the largest ecosystems in the World, generating half of the oxygen we breathe. Over 3 billion people depend on marine and coastal biodiversity for their livelihoods and protein. Medicinal products come from the ocean that help to battle cancer, heart disease and Covid-19. Oceans absorb about 30% of carbon dioxide produced by humans. This helps to buffer the ongoing impacts of Global Warming. Ocean processes regulate the climate, mediate temperature and determine the weather.

UN World Oceans day is a celebration and reminder of the role that the oceans play in everyday life! The Purpose of the day is to inform the public of the impact of human actions on the ocean, develop a worldwide movement of citizens for the ocean, and mobilize and unite the world's population on a project for the sustainable management of the world's oceans. The theme for 2020 was Innovation for a Sustainable Ocean, leading up to the UN's decade of Ocean Science which will run between 2021-2030.

The Thermohaline Conveyor transports heat around the World helping to regulate the Earth's climate. The warm waters of the gulf stream flow across the Atlantic and heat parts of Northern Europe by up to 10 degrees in the winter months. As the Gulf stream reaches the Arctic Ocean it cools and turns to flow south. However, this flow has weakened by 20% over the past 50 years. Thermohaline circulation is driven by differences in slainity and temperature in water, so continued Glacial melt could have adverse effects on this process, potentially plunging Western Europe into a colder climate. However, this is unlikely to happen any time soon!

sections.subheading: How is Climate Change affecting the oceans?
body: Coral Bleaching - Many Coral Reefs, including the Great Barrier Reef are dying. Coral bleaching results in the shrinkage, starvation and eventual death of corals that support thousands of species
Wetlands - Rising sea levels are drowning wetlands that can not grow at a fast enough rate to stay above water.
Fish Stock - Reports suggest fish are moving towards the poles in response to increased ocean warming. This heavily impacts fisheries around the World and destroys ecosystems.
Acidification - the trends in ocean acidification are 30 times greater than natural variation. Ocean acidity affects many ocean species abilities to form shells.

name: Burning
summary: What is Burning and how does it affect the environment?

sections.__comment9__: Contents of the section which can be seperated into multiple paragraphs
body: To be on fire is to undergo rapid combustion or consume fuel in such a way as to give off heat, gases, and usually, light. A range of substances are burned every day, such as wood, fossil fuels, vegetation, and plastics. Most of the waste we discard is not sent to landfill, but is burnt to produce energy. Each one of these examples are having disastrous effects on the environment, wildlife, and our health.

Farmers in many parts of the world set fire to cultivated fields to clear stubble, weeds and waste before sowing a new crop. Whilst this may be fast and economical, it also reduces the fertility of the soil and produces large quantities of black carbon. Open burning accounts for more than one third of all black carbon emissions. This in turn leads to increased air pollution and the production of greenhouse gases, which we all know accelerates anthropogenic climate change. Many of the fires witnessed in the Amazon rainforest are a result of this practice, something which is being actively encouraged by President Bolsonaro.

The burning of plastics releases toxic gases like dioxins, furans, mercury and BCPs into the atmosphere. This poses a threat to vegetation, animals, and human health. Plastic waste burning increases the risk of heart disease; aggravates respiratory illnesses, such as asthma; and can damage the nervous system. The burning of plastic waste has been proposed as an alternative to the burning of fossil fuels. However, this an extremely carbon and methane intensive process which is also less efficient.

Non-renewable fuels - which include coal, oil, and natural gas - supply about 80% of the world’s energy. Carbon dioxide emissions from burning coal account for 44% of the global total, and it's the biggest single source of the global temperature increase above pre-industrial levels. Fossil Fuel extraction and burning have also led to a number of environmental disasters, such as the Exxon Valdez spill in 1989 and the Deepwater Horizon disaster in 2010.

name: Migration
summary: How is Climate Change and Global Warming affecting Migratory patterns?

body: Migration is a strategy and behavioural adaption employed by a range of animals to help them survive. These migrations can vary in distance with some species like the Atlantic Salmon travelling thousands of miles, whilst others such as toads travel very short distances. Multiple factors can drive migration, including: movement to more hospitable climates when local conditions become unfavourable, and breeding.

Migratory animals are essential components of the ecosystems that support life on Earth. They act as pollinators and help to disperse seeds, which plays a vital role in maintaining ecosystem structure. They provide a source of food for other animals and help to regulate the population of species in ecosystems. Migratory species play a large role in how we measure time and experience seasons.

sections.subheading: How is Climate Change affecting migration?
body: Land-based species are moving poleward by an average of 17km per decade, and marine species by 72km per decade. Climate Change is making areas more viable for certain species: Malaria, for example, now appears higher up mountain slopes in Colombia and Ethiopia, as mosquitoes are able to live at higher elevations. Migratory species are especially at risk due to Climate Change because the require a range of habitats. Often, one or more of these habitats are at risk. This means that many migratory species will need to quickly find ways to adapt or face extinction.

Animals such as sea turtles, return to the same beach every year to lay their eggs. Some crustaceans such as crabs migrate for breeding purposes. In many species, the females move to shallow coastal waters to mate and lay their eggs before they then return to deeper ocean waters. The Whooping Crane breeds on the Canadian border before migrating 4,000 kilometres to Texas for the winter.

name: Refugees
summary: How is climate change contributing to a refugee crisis, and how can we support refugees

body: Global sea levels are set to rise by a minimum of 2.6 feet by 2100. This can - and will - leave many island and coastal populations (Particularly in the Global South) at risk of becoming climate refugees. This is an imminent threat that could leave more than 140 million people displaced from their homes. This is compounded by the fact that the Met Office has seen an increase in extreme weather events in the last 40 years.

The ongoing refugee crisis will cause mass displacement, and is already a topic of extreme contention with concerns on the potential strain on welfare systems. The climate crisis is breaking apart communities that have existed for thousands of years.

Populations are being forced to flee from the effects of changing climate, which is evidenced to create more frequent and severe extreme weather events, including: Drought; Flooding; Desertification; Wild fires and Tropical storms. However, these popualtions are not legally recognised as refugees and therefore do not have legal protection.
In 2015, the first application of refugee status in line with climatic impacts was made in New Zealand by the Teitota family from the island of Kiribati. Their case was ultimately dismissed.

The Federated states of Micronesia have seen a drastic reduction in size due to rising sea levels and have had their fresh water contaminated by sea water (see S), leaving people increasingly vulnerable. These island communities have small populations and due to their less-economically empowered position are struggling to get their voices heard.

In Bangladesh, increased coastal flooding is causing millions of people to relocate to slums in cities such as Dhaka, where they face poor sanitation, high crime rates and extreme poverty. It is predicted that by 2050, the number of Bangladeshi’s displaced by Climate Change will be 13.3 million.

name: Sea Level Rise
summary: What causes sea level rise and why is this a problem?

sections.subheading: What's Happening to Global Sea Levels?
body: Global sea levels have risen by 8 inches since 1880, and the rate of sea level rise is only getting faster, with oceans rising an average of 3.2 millimeters per year globally. Sea levels could increase up to 2 meters by 2100, threatening many low lying areas.The cause? Excessive production of greenhouse gas emissions through practices such as deforestation, petrol conumption, fossil fuel burning and agriculture.

Warming temperatures don't just melt a few ice caps, our oceans are also being affected by a process known as thermal expansion. Due to the greenhouse effect (see G for more on that!), oceans are warming. If you remember anything from your school chemistry lessons, you might remember that heat caauses water to expand. This is exactly what's happening to our oceans, causing an increase in volume and producing higher sea levels.

Increased melting of ice is to partially blame as well of course. Melting of icecaps from atmospheric warming and feedback mechanisms such as the albedo effect (check out F and A for the facts) contributes additional water to our oceans, some which has been locked in glaciers for many many years. Global warming is not a uniform process, and the arctic is heating at twice the rate of anywhere else on the planet. Greenlands glaciers pose the biggest threat to sea level rise, home to 2.96 million cubic kilometers of ice. It is important to not that melting sea ice does not directly contribute to rising sea levels. Just as a drink with ice in it will not overflow when the ice melts, sea ice is already accounted for in our ocean's volume. However, due to the albedo effect, melting sea ice reveals more dark ocean beneath it which will both absorb more solar energy, and contribute additional water that will expand as it heats.

Rising sea levels threaten low lying coastal areas, from the Maldives, to New York, Singapore and beyond. Changing sea levels also risk the contamination of drinking water supplies - with porous aquifers absorbing the rising salt water. In Florida, limestone aquifers that provide drinking water to nearly 6 million people are increasingly polluted by salt water due to rising sea levels and unsustainable quantities of ground water being removed.

There are many more impacts of sea level rise, from increased coastal erosion due to the loss of protective beaches; amplified storm surges with the power to be more destructive; and even the loss of habitat for fish and birds due to the loss of coastal habitats!

So, as you can tell, sea level rise isn't going to be ideal. It's easy to start feeling anxious and overwhelmed about these impacts - trust me, we've all been there! But there are solutions, you can urge your local (and less local) officials to commit to mitigating and protecting against flooding. We also need to tackle the root cause - decreasing our greenhouse gas emissions and removing carbon dioxide and other harmful gases from our atmosphere. One effective solution that can also work to protect coastal areas are protecting and conserving wetlands and peatlands (areas where the remains of vegetation are compressed in waterlogged conditions). Peatlands have the potential of storing up to 550 gigatonnes of carbon - in fact they are the largest terrestrial store of carbon in the world! They have real potential to help with carbon removal, but damaged peatlands can contribute significant greenhouse gases. Championing for the preservation of our natural resources is one thing you can do if you want to help mitigate the flood risk of sea level rise, and contribute to tackling the climate crisis!

name: The IPCC
summary: Who are the IPCC, and what predictions have they made?

sections.subheading: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). Who are they?
body: A group of experts from around the world providing regular scientific assessments on climate change to policymakers.
They display the potential future risks of climate change on the planet, suggesting a range of ways to adapt current behaviours in order to reduce these risks.

sections.subheading: How do they form these assessments?
body: The IPCC is comprised of 3 working groups. Working group I who focus on The Physical Science Basis of Climate Change, Working group II focusing on Climate Change Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability, and Working group III who look at the Mitigation of climate change.

Process: Select working group authors - Assess literature - First draft - Expert review of first draft - Second order draft and Summary for Policymakers - Review - Final draft and government approval - Snthesis report created

Limiting warming to 1.5'C instead of 2'C would have clear benefits to both people and the environment, however this would take unprecedented societal changes. By 2100 global sea level rise would be 10cm lower with 1.5'C warming compared to 2'C. Rather than a complete loss with a 2'C increase, coral reefs would decline by 70-90% with 1.5'C warming. A warming of greater than 1.5'C increases the risk of irreversible change (e.g. extinction of ecosystems). Keeping warming to 1.5'C allows ecosystems the chance to adapt to changes.

sections.subheading: What can you do to help?
body: Stay educated and cut your carbon footprint!

Cut your carbon footprint to help society stick to the 1.5'C of warming (see Y for more!). Stay up to date with future IPCC reports to show you how you can continue to help the climate crisis. Raise awareness! Join environmental groups (see X for an example) to educate others on the climate crisis to unite society in the fight against climate change

name: Carbon Sink
summary: What's a carbon sink and how do they work?

body: A carbon sink is anything that absorbs more carbon dioxide than it gives out. Carbon sinks are a crucial tool in the fight against climate change as they reduce the amount of carbon emissions in the atmosphere. This is known as carbon sequestration – the process of capturing and storing atmospheric carbon dioxide.

sections.subheading: What are some real life examples?
body: Forests are one of the most well-known examples of a carbon sink: trees sequester carbon by capturing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and transforming  it into biomass through photosynthesis. This is the main way carbon offsetting occurs: Carbon accumulates in the form of biomass, soils and deadwood. Whilst this is a brilliant natural phenomenon, increased deforestation leads to this stored carbon being released back into the atmosphere. This is one reason why deforestation is so bad for the planet, by turning a natural carbon sink into a source of additional emissions.

Our oceans are another vast carbon sink – the largest on earth. Staggeringly, the earth’s oceans have absorbed as much as 1/3rd of the CO2 that humans have produced since the start of the Industrial Revolution. This is all part of the carbon cycle, which affects how much carbon the ocean can absorb. Some scientists are finding that human-induced warming is affecting the rate at which carbon is absorbed.

name: Diversity
summary: Diversity and Intersectional Environmentalism, what's it all about?

sections.__comment9__: Contents of the section which can be seperated into multiple paragraphs
body: Intersectional environmentalism refers to the understanding that the injustices happening to the earth also have an overlapping social aspect. Diversity is a key issue in the environmental conversation as issues such as ethnic or racial marginalisation, gender discrimination and poverty all shape, or are shaped by, environmental justice. Indeed, research shows that climate change disproportionately affects ethnic and sexual minority groups and working-class people; yet the climate movement is often dominated by white, middle class individuals.

According to GreenBiz, “bridging cultural liaisons aboard the corporate sustainability teams can help bridge gaps, broaden an organisation’s positive influence and reach, all while bringing in new perspectives and strategies.” In reality, the sustainability sector is lacking in diversity. In 2015, Craig Bennett as CEO of Friends of the Earth referred to the green movement as a “white, middle-class ghetto.” Research has also found that UK environmental professions are the least diverse.

Many have criticised XR for being exclusive, as promoting civil disobedience and praising arrest shows a lack of sensitivity for groups who cannot afford to be arrested. This means groups with less privilege may feel excluded from the movement. On the other hand, the recent school strikes fronted by Greta Thunberg have been praised for their inclusivity, sensitive protest methods and for showcasing different voices.

name: Justice & Climate Change
summary: What are the social justice implications of climate change, and why do these matter?

body: According to the often cited definition by the US Environmental Protection Agency, it is the ‘fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people, regardless of race, colour, national origin or income, with respect to the development, implementation and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations and policies’.

sections.subheading: What kicked off the Environmental Justice Movement?
body: Between the 1930s and 1978, 82% of all waste in Houston, Texas, was dumped in black neighbourhoods, even though only 25% of the local population was black. This was targeted and widespread practice in many areas. This case became the foundation for environmental social justice movements across the world, illuminating similar practices and injustices elsewhere.

This involves seeing the ethical and civil rights side of climate change, rather than focusing on just the scientific, considering how the impacts of climate change are unequally distributed. The world’s poorest and most vulnerable communities are the most hit by the impacts of climate change, despite contributing the lowest levels of global emissions per capita.

Take Kiribati as an example. The capital city of this small island, where nearly half the country resides, will be 25%-80% flooded by 2050 unless significant adaptation is taken. This is a climate justice issue because the nation is amongst the lowest ranking carbon producers in the world, releasing 0.1MtCO2 each year.

sections.subheading: Unequal Ecological Exchange – What is it?
body: A school of thought that focuses on the injustices incurred from the exporting of hazardous, polluting and environmentally damaging activities from developed countries to less developed countries. Research suggests that participation in international trade increases CO2 emissions in poorer countries while lowering them in wealthier ones due to the outsourcing of polluting industries, and the negative environmental impacts that come with it, to less developed countries. This has led to the idea that richer countries owe an ‘ecological debt’ to poorer nations in the form of local environmental damages resulting from producing energy-intensive goods for richer nations.

name: Veganism
summary: Does veganism actually benefit the planet?

sections.subheading: What is Veganism and How Does it Relate to Climate Change?
body: Veganism is a lifestyle that excludes, as far as possible, all forms of animal products for food, clothing or any other purposes . The lifestyle, with its roots in ethics and environmentalism, has increased in its uptake significantly in recent years, concurrently with a shift towards more environmental consciousness among popular culture.

There’s no better time to parade the benefits of a vegan diet: alongside with the ticking time-bomb that is global warming with its myriad socio-ecological impacts, veganism highlights the importance of our exploitative relationship with nature and the role this plays in the spread of disease (SARS, Ebola and most likely COVID-19 are just the recent ones) . That’s why we’ve broken down the key facts surrounding veganism and the environment, as well as providing you with actionable recommendations to incorporate veganism into your life.

Did you know that greenhouse gas emissions from animal agriculture rank higher than all transport-related emissions worldwide? That’s more than all the planes, buses, cars, lorries and trains combined. The livestock sector represents nearly 20% of global annual greenhouse gas emissions (in Co2 equivalent), and is responsible for 65% of all human-related emissions of nitrous oxide – a greenhouse gas with 296 times the global warming potential of carbon dioxide.

Cows alone produce 150 billion gallons of methane per day – with methane possessing a global warming potential 86 times that of CO2 on a 20 year time frame. Moreover, livestock occupy over 30% of global arable land. Let us say that again. One-third of the earth’s surface is covered by animals grown for livestock. With this comes mass deforestation: our precious Amazon is just one of the victims; with 80% current deforestation providing space for cattle grazing.

sections.subheading: What can you do about it?
body: Going vegan might seem like a massive step that you're not ready for, or maybe you don't know where to start going green? So we've compiled a small guide to give you some asssitance!

1) Prepare yourself. Do your research. Make a list of essentials for your cupboard and fridge, ensuring you're getting a wide variety of nuts, gtains, fruit and vegetables and vitamins. Expand your knowledge. Read and watch documentaries (Cowspiracy, Gamechangers, Forks over Knives and What the Health are some gems on Netflix).

2) Realise that it's not a competition. For some, cutting out animal profucts is a big adjustment and it's important to remember that it will take time. You can start with cutting out a couple of things, leaving the hardest until last (for many this is cheese or chocolate!). That way, you can stagger the transition and ease yourself in.

3) Learn about substitutes. There's so much fun to be had in the kitchen cooking vehan food as you have to be much more creative with ingrefients: who knew you could make cheese sauces from cashews or egg replacements from chickpea water (aka aquafaba... Trust us)!
4) Get ready to read lots of labels! You would be surprised at the number of products milk can sneak into. But don't feel bad if you slip up. Remember that what you're doing is making a difference!

5) Finally, remember to have fun. Veganism is a lifestyle built off a sense of compassion for the earth, so remember to be compassionate to yourself too. It can be overwhelming sometimes, and you may wish you could do more. Remember that there are hundreds of thousands of others feeling the same around the world making an impact as a collective consumer. Try out the vegan calculator to quantify your impact!

name: Quaternary Period
summary: What is the Quaternary Period and what does it teach us about climate change?

sections.__comment9__: Contents of the section which can be seperated into multiple paragraphs
body: The Quaternary Period is the geological time period that we are currently in, which encompasses the last 2.6 million years. The Quaternary Period is composed of two 'epochs', which are subdivisions of a geological period. The two epochs making up the Quaternary are called the Pleistocene and the Holocene. We are currently in the Holocene, however, there is debate about the start of a new epoch.

The Pleistocene epoch stretches from 2.6 million years ago (the start of the Quaternary) to 11,000 years before present. This epoch makes up the majority of the Quaternary Period and is characterised by more than 50 large-scale climate oscillations, from cold glacial intervals, lasting as long as 100,000 years, to warm interglacial intervals, lasting up to 10,000 years. The most recent glacial cycle occurred roughly 115,000-11,700 years ago.

The Holocene epoch is the current interglacial interval which began 11,000 years ago and continues to the present day. Human civilisations and modern flora and fauna have arisen during the Holocene as the Earth entered a warmer trend. Agriculture is one of the primary ways in which human civilisations developed. The cultivation of wheat, barley, rice and other plants and the domestication of animals began roughly 8,000 years ago.

A proposed new geological epoch coined by the Nobel Prize winning chemist, Paul Crutzen, in 2002. Crutzen suggested that because human activities have had such a significant impact on the fabric of the earth, through agriculture, urbanisation, and fossil fuel burning, it is justifiable to claim we have entered a new epoch. Many agree with this proposition, but much debate surrounds when this period began. The International Commission on Stratigraphy are currently debating proof of the Anthropocene and are looking for a 'Golden Spike' - a marker in the fossil record which could demarcate the Holocene from the Anthropocene.

Studies of past geological epochs and climates help climate scientists predict future warming and provide a contextual record for which to compare and argue the case for anthropogenic greenhouse warming. Ice cores taken across locations in Antarctica and Greenland ice sheets contain ancient air bubbles trapped in the glaciers. Scientists can test these to determine concentrations of past greenhouse gases in comparison to those we measure today. These are called proxies for the understanding of past epochs. Scientists have shown that both the levels of present-day greenhouse gases and the rate of increase is anomalous in comparison to the past 800,000 years. Maximum methane levels reached 800 ppl over the past 650 thousand years, compared to present day levels of over 1800 ppl. CO2 levels in the late Quaternary ranged between approximately 170 to 300 ppm, in stark contrast to CO2 levels of 416 ppm recorded presently. Kopp et al (2009) claimed that a doubling of CO2 levels is enough to cause a 2 - 4.5 degree rise in climate sensitivity, stating that current levels are sufficient to produce a warming of 1.4 - 3.2 degrees increase in global temperatures.

With the IPCC stressing the importance of limiting warming to under 1.5 degrees centigrade, it is important we work towards a carbon neutral future and keep up pressure on officials and corporations to ensure they take responsibility.

name: Natural Disasters
summary: How does climate change relate to natural disasters, and are they expected to get worse?

sections.subheading: How do you define a natural disaster?
body: Natural disasters are a naturally occurring physical phenomena caused either by rapid or slow onset events which can be:
Geophysical - events caused by the movements and processes of the Earth, such as earthquakes, tsunamis, landslides and volcanoes.
Hydrological - relating to changes in precipitation or bodies of H2O, such as avalanches and floods.
Climatological - events associated with the climate, general or long-term weather conditions such as widespread droughts.
Meteorological - localised weather conditions which can create freak extreme weather events, such as tropical storms/cyclones/typhoons.
Biological - disease epidemics/pandemics and insect/animal plagues.

sections.subheading: What are the impacts of climate change on natural disasters?
body: Mounting evidence suggests that changes in the global climate exacerbates climate hazards and amplifies the risk of extreme weather disasters. An increase in global surface temperatures is likely to result in more droughts and increased intensity of storms. As more water vapour is evaporated into the atmosphere, due to increased ice-melt, it becomes fuel for more powerful storms. More heat in the atmosphere and warmer ocean surface temperatures is likely to lead to increased wind speeds and tropical storms.

sections.subheading: A growing trend of more destructive natural disasters?
body: Cyclones Idai and Kenneth hit Southern Africa in 2019, taking the lives of 1000+ people, hitting areas where no tropical cyclone has been observed since the satellite era. The start of 2020 found Australia in the midst of its worst-ever bushfire season, following on from its hottest year on record which had left soil and vegetation extremely dry, easily catching on fire and fuelling it further. Moreover, higher sea temperatures have doubled the likelihood of drought in the Horn of Africa region. Severe droughts in 2011, 2017 and 2019 have repeatedly wiped out crops and livestock. However, in India, Nepal and Bangladesh, exceptionally heavy monsoon rains and intense flooding destroyed, killed and devastated lives just two years ago.

Body: Natural disasters affect all countries, rich and poor, but as we face a future of enhanced risks it is critical we face the reality of those who bear the burden of our changing climate. People in less economically developed countries are at least four times more likely to be displaced by extreme weather than people in more economically developed countries. There is a strong intersection between economic and social factors which result in individuals facing extreme vulnerability. When Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans, black LGBTQ+ communities were devastated, with many refused shelter due to their sexuality. Over a decade later, the community still haven't fully recovered. In Kingston, Jamaica, much of the LGBTQ+ community have faced disownment by families and have resorted to living in camps on the outskirts of the city in coastal areas. They will be the first hit by tropical storms and least equipped to prepare and manage the aftermath.

The world faces a race against time to reduce emissions and help the most vulnerable cope with climate impacts that are already being faced today and will only escalate in the years ahead. It's time to act now. Donate to relief funds, Black Lives Matter charities or LGBTQ+ charities such as Stonewall or the Albert Kennedy Trust. Push leaders to commit to emissions reduction and do your bit to help.

name: Local
summary: How does shopping locally help reduce your carbon footprint, especially from food?

body: You can get anything you want delivered to your front door by tomorrow in just one click, but is this sustainable? A growing consumer appetite for convenience is taking its toll on the environment. By 2030, urban last-mile delivery emissions (from the final leg of a journey to get a product to the consumer) are set to increase by more than 30% in 100 cities globally.

Transporting food within, to and around the UK produces 19 million tonnes of CO2 annually, equivalent to around 5.5 million typical cars. Different foods also incur different carbon footprints, do you know the average greenhouse gases in your lunch? We know there's a lot of information out there, and it gets pretty overwhelming. You can use the BBC's Climate Change Food Calculator to estimate the footprint of your plate (check out the references below!). Some examples are:
Avocados: 0.2kg
Tomatoes: 0.16kg
Berries and grapes: 0.125kg
Bananas: 0.06kg
Citrus fruits: 0.03kg

sections.subheading: What are the benefits of shopping locally?
body: When you shop at local butchers, bakers, farm shops and green grocers; it is likely that the majority of the produce has a shorter field-to-fork journey than large supermarkets, this incurs a much smaller carbon footprint. You will also be supporting your local economy and independent businesses. Research on spending shows that for every £1 spent with a small or medium-sized business, 63p stays within the local economy, compared to 40p for larger organisations. That's nearly one third more! Moreover, many farmers participating in local farmers' markets use organic non-GMO and chemical free methods to grow their own produce, and often use less plastic packaging also.

sections.body: Independent grocers often have a reputation of being a pricier alternative to supermarkets, and while some can't afford the discount bulk prices of supermarkets - they often have a lower mark-up rate on groceries. It's worth doing a bit go digging in your local area to see what your options are. Seasonal markets might also give you the opportunity to practice your haggling skills, or reduce prices towards the end of their opening hours to make sure all fresh produce gets bought and none is wasted. Independent and local food outlets will provide you with delicious seasonal produce grown locally, so you can be sure that your plate has a low carbon footprint.
